ch.ecma.csta.physical

Interface PhysicalDeviceServices


  • public interface PhysicalDeviceServices
    Provides access to physical device services as related to a physical element of the device.

    Prerequisites Before attempting to use PhysicalDeviceServices, do the following:

    1. Acquire an instance of ServiceProvider by using the ServiceProvider.getServiceProvider method.
    2. Acquire an instance of PhysicalDeviceServices by using the ServiceProvider.getService method.
    3. Get a device ID from DeviceServices and gain exclusive control of the device by registering the device using TerminalServices.
    4. Implement a PhysicalDeviceListener and add it using MonitoringServices.addPhysicalDeviceListener so that the application is prepared to receive events before they occur.

    Clean Up When you are finished with this service, remove any listeners that were added for that device using MonitoringServices.removePhysicalDeviceListener.

    Note that not all of the requests and for these services may be supported. In these cases, the request description will state that it is not supported.
    Similarly, not all of the parameters may be supported for a given request, or for any associated events. In these cases, the description of the request (or event) will contain a table of the parameters that are supported.

    Implementation of CSTA's General Functional Requirements

    1. The device identifier supplied on each Physical Device service shall be the device identifier associated with the physical element of the device. Otherwise, the request is rejected with a negative acknowledgement.
    2. Switching functions will be rejected if the physical device has not previously been "registered" (see TerminalServices).
    When using the Physical Device Services to make a call, we recommend that your application wait 1 second after going off-hook and before dialing digits. If your application is activating a feature via a FAC such as Call Forwarding or Service Observing, we recommend that your application wait 1 second after dialing the FAC and before dialing more digits. The API does not receive call progress events and incorporating these two timer mechanisms into your application allows Communication Manager to be ready to receive the digits.
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.8 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.
    See Also:
    "ECMA-269, sections 6.1.3 Device, 6.1.3.1 Physical Element, 6.7.2 Monitoring, and 21 Physical Device Features."

    • Method Detail

      • pressButton

        ButtonPressResponse pressButton(ButtonPress request)
                         throws CstaException
        Simulates the activation of a specified button on a device. The CSTA button model is described in Button. See the ButtonPress request for more information.

        The button parameter of the ButtonPress request specifies the address of the button to be pressed on the device. Use the constant enumerations in the ButtonIDConstants class.

        For example, to press the number 5, specify the ButtonIDConstant called DIAL_PAD_5. To press the pound sign (#), specify the ButtonIDConstant called DIAL_PAD_POUND. Warning: Specifying "#" or "*" will not work. You must use the ButtonIDConstants.

        Here is an example of how you might request that the conference button be pressed: 

         ButtonPress request = new ButtonPress();
 request.setDevice(device);
 request.setButton(ButtonIDConstants.CONFERENCE);
        Parameters:
        request - a ButtonPress request indicating which button to press on what device.
        Returns:
        a ButtonPressResponse that positively acknowledges receipt of your request. The request parameters look valid and the request is being processed. No useful information is returned in the response.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet
        InvalidButtonIdentifierException - indicates that the button module is not in the acceptable range
        ButtonNotSupportedException - indicates that the button is not assigned
        OperationException - indicates that a operational error has occurred
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - indicates that the request or the DeviceID inside the request is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getAuditoryApparatusInformation

      • getButtonInformation

        GetButtonInformationResponse getButtonInformation(GetButtonInformation request)
                                           throws CstaException
        Get the button information for either a specified button or all buttons on a device. Use this request to determine a button's function, associated number, indicators, and lamps, if applicable. Descriptions of button attributes are in Button. See the GetButtonInformation request for more information.

        Here is an example of how a GetButtonInformation request is setup to request information on all buttons for the device: 

         GetButtonInformation request = new GetButtonInformation();
 request.setDevice (device);

        Here is an example of how you might extract button information from the GetButtonInformationResponse: 

         GetButtonInformation request = new GetButtonInformation();
 request.setDevice();
 GetButtonInformationResponse response = service.getButtonInformation(request);
 ButtonItems[] items = response.getButtonList().getButtonItem();
 for (int i=0; i < items.length;i++) {
         ButtonItem item = items[i];
         System.out.println(item.getButtonFunction());
 }
        See ButtonIDConstants for the complete list of Button ID constant definitions and ButtonFunctionConstants for Button function constant definitions.

        Parameters:
        request - a GetButtonInformation service request that indicates which button on which device you desire information about. If no specific button is specified, information for all of the device's buttons is returned.
        Returns:
        a GetButtonInformationResponse containing the requested button information.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet
        InvalidButtonIdentifierException - indicates that the button address is not in the acceptable range
        ButtonNotSupportedException - indicates that the button is not assigned
        OperationException - indicates that a operational error has occurred
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - indicates that either the request or the DeviceID inside the request are null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getDisplay

        GetDisplayResponse getDisplay(GetDisplay request)
                       throws CstaException
        Get a snapshot of the contents of the physical device's display. The returned information for the display includes the current contents of the display. See the GetDisplay request for more information.

        Here is an example of how you might extract display information from the GetDisplayResponse: 

         GetDisplay request = new GetDisplay();
 request.setDevice(device);
 GetDisplayResponse response = physDevServ.getDisplay(request);
 DisplayListItems[] items = response.getDisplayList().getDisplayListItem();
 for(int i=0; i < items.length;i++) {
   System.out.println(items[i].getContentsOfDisplay());
 }
        Parameters:
        request - a GetDisplay request that indicates which device and display you are interested in. If a specific display is not indicated, then information for all displays on the device is provided in the response.
        Returns:
        a GetDisplayResponse containing the requested display information
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with theDeviceID.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet.
        OperationException - indicates that a operational error has occurred.
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getHookswitchStatus

        GetHookswitchStatusResponse getHookswitchStatus(GetHookswitchStatus request)
                                         throws CstaException
        Get the hookswitch status of a specified device. The hookswitch status indicates whether the device is currently on or off hook. See the GetHookswitchStatus request for more information. 
         GetHookswitchStatus request = new GetHookswitchStatus();
 request.setDevice();
 GetHookswitchStatusResponse response = physDevServ.getHookswitchStatus(request);
 HookswitchStatusListItems[] items = response.getHookswitchStatusListItem();
 for(int i=0; i < items.length;i++) {
   System.out.println(items[i].getHookswitchOnHook());
 }
        Parameters:
        request - a GetHookswitchStatus request which specifies a device.
        Returns:
        a GetHookswitchStatusResponse indicating whether the hookswitch is on or off hook
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet
        OperationException - indicates that a operational error has occurred
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getLampMode

        GetLampModeResponse getLampMode(GetLampMode request)
                         throws CstaException
        Get the lamp mode status for either a specified button or all buttons on a device. Also includes information on the green color lamp and associated button, if applicable. See the GetLampMode request for more information.

        The response returns a list of Lamp Mode Items which contain the lamp mode, color and associated button.

        The complete set of possible values for the LampMode parameter specific to Communication Manager is:

        • LampModeConstants.BROKENFLUTTER
        • LampModeConstants.FLASH
        • LampModeConstants.FLUTTER
        • LampModeConstants.INVERTEDFLASH
        • LampModeConstants.INVERTEDWINK
        • LampModeConstants.OFF
        • LampModeConstants.STEADY
        • LampModeConstants.WINK
        The complete set of possible values for the lampColor parameter specific to Communication Manager is:
        • LampModeConstants.RED
        • LampModeConstants.GREEN
        Currently, only information for green lamps is returned.

        Here is an example of how you would request a lamp's mode and how you would extract information from the response to determine whether the lamp is on STEADY or not: 

         GetLampMode request = new GetLampMode();
 request.setDevice(device);
 GetLampModeResponse response = physDevServ.getLampMode(request);
 LampModeItems[] items = response.getLampModeList().getLampModeItem();
 for(int i=0; i < items.length; i++) {
   if(LampModeConstants.STEADY.equals(items[i].getLampMode())) {
     System.out.println(items[i].getLamp() + " is Steady");
   }
 }
        Parameters:
        request - a GetLampMode request specifying which lamp to query. If not provided, then the lamp mode is obtained on all the lamps associated with the device.
        Returns:
        a GetLampModeRepsonse indicating lamp mode (flutter, steady, off, etc.), associated button, and color.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet.
        InvalidLampIDException - indicates that the lamp module is not in the acceptable range.
        LampNotSupportedException - indicates that the lamp is not assigned.
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - indicates that either the request or the DeviceID inside the request are null.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getMessageWaitingIndicator

        GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse getMessageWaitingIndicator(GetMessageWaitingIndicator request)
                                                       throws CstaException
        Supported in a future release.

        Get the message waiting status at a specified device. The message waiting feature is typically used to notify a user (typically via a dedicated lamp on a phone device) when messages are available. See the GetMessageWaitingIndicator request for more information.

        Parameters:
        request - a GetMessageWaitingIndicator request specifying which device to query.
        Returns:
        a GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse indicates whether the message waiting indicator on the device is on or off or if there is no message waiting indicator.
        Optional parameters are supported in the private data area with an Avaya-specified GetMessageWaitingIndicatorPrivateData object. This private data object contains the application type(s) which turned on the message waiting indicator.

        The device id in the request can be either a first party device id or a third-party device id. The device id must be a third-party device id to receive the Avaya-specified GetMessageWaitingIndicatorPrivateData in the response.

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use GetMessageWaitingIndicator using a third-part device id.
        Receiving the response is an indication that the request succeeded. 

         GetMessageWaitingIndicator request = new GetMessageWaitingIndicator(); 
 // deviceID is a DeviceID that was retrieved  
 // using DeviceServices.getThirdPartyDeviceID(GetThirdPartyDeviceId)
 request.setDevice(deviceID);
 GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse response = physicalDeviceServices.getMessageWaitingIndicator(request);
 // print the messageWaiting status of the device
 System.out.println("Device: " + deviceID.getContent(); + 
      " MWI status: " + response.getMessageWaitingOn());
 // get the application(s) that turned on the messagewaiting 
 if ((response() != null) && (response().getSinglePrivateData() instanceof GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponsePrivateData)) {
   GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponsePrivateData privData = (GetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponsePrivateData)response.getExtensions().getSinglePrivateData();
   MWIApplicationType[] appTypes = privData.getMwiApplicationType();
   for(MWIApplicationType current:appTypes) {
       System.out.println("mwiType=" + current.toString());
   }
 }
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID.
        SubscribedResourceAvailabilityException - indicates that the station is a SIP station and the 'Type of 3PCC Enabled' administered for the station is not set to 'Avaya'
        OperationException - indicates that an operational error has occurred.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getRingerStatus

        GetRingerStatusResponse getRingerStatus(GetRingerStatus request)
                                 throws CstaException
        Get the ringer status of the ringer associated with a device. This allows a computing function to determine:
        • if a ringer is engaged in a ringing cycle
        • the ring pattern

        See the GetRingerStatus request for more information.

        The response returns a list of Ringer Status Items which contain the ringerID, ring mode and ring pattern.

        The complete set of possible values for the RingMode parameter specific to Communication Manager is:

        • RingMode.RINGING - The ringer is ringing (provided when either the ringer is physically ringing or is in the quiet phase of a ring cycle)
        • RingMode.NOTRINGING - The ringer is not being rung.
        The complete set of possible values for the RingPatter is found in RingerPatternConstants.

        Here an example of how to create a request and extract data from the response: 

         GetRingerStatus request = new GetRingerStatus();
 request.setDevice();
 GetRingerStatusResponse response = physDevServ.getRingerStatus(request);
 RingerStatusListItem[] items = response.getRingerStatusListItem();
 for(int i=0; i < items.length;i++) {
   if (RingMode.RINGING.equals(items[i].getRingMode())) {
     Long pattern = items[i].getRingPattern();
     if (RingerPatternConstants.ATTENDANT_EMERGENCY.equals(pattern)) {
       System.out.println("Ringing with ATTENDANT_EMERGENCY pattern.");
     }
   }
 }
        Parameters:
        request - a GetRingerStatus request specifying which ringer on a specified device to query.
        Returns:
        a GetRingerStatusResponse which includes the ring mode and ring pattern.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet
        OperationException - indicates that a operational error has occurred
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - indicates that either the request or the DeviceID inside the request are null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • setHookswitchStatus

        SetHookswitchStatusResponse setHookswitchStatus(SetHookswitchStatus request)
                                         throws CstaException
        Set the hookswitch status of a specified device. This service allows the computing function to go on or off hook at the specified device. See the SetHookswitchStatus request for more information.
        Parameters:
        request - a SetHookswitchStatus request specifying whether the specified device is to be set on or off hook.
        Returns:
        an empty SetHookswitchStatusResponse
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        InvalidDeviceStateException - indicates that the station is not available to use - not registered yet
        OperationException - indicates that an operational error has occurred
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - indicates that either the request or the DeviceID inside the request are null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • setMessageWaitingIndicator

        SetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse setMessageWaitingIndicator(SetMessageWaitingIndicator request)
                                                       throws CstaException
        Supported in a future release.

        Set the message waiting indicator service allows a computing function to control the status of the message waiting feature at a specified device. The message waiting feature is typically used to notify a user (typically via a dedicated lamp on a phone device) when messages are available. See the SetMessageWaitingIndicator request for more information.

        Parameters:
        request - a SetMessageWaitingIndicator request specifying whether the message indicator at the specified device is to be set on or off.
        Returns:
        an empty SetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse

        Example: The following code gives an example of how to use SetMessageWaitingIndicator.
        Receiving the response is an indication that the request succeeded. 

         SetMessageWaitingIndicator request = new SetMessageWaitingIndicator(); 
 // deviceID is a DeviceID that was retrieved  
 // using DeviceServices.getThirdPartyDeviceID(GetThirdPartyDeviceId)
 request.setDevice(deviceID);
 request.setDeviceForMessage(deviceID);
 request.setMessageWaitingOn(true);
 
 SetMessageWaitingIndicatorResponse response = physicalDeviceServices.setMessageWaitingIndicator(request);
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID.
        SubscribedResourceAvailabilityException - indicates that the station is a SIP station and the 'Type of 3PCC Enabled' administered for the station is not set to 'Avaya'
        OperationException - indicates that an operational error has occurred.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • addPhysicalDeviceListener

        void addPhysicalDeviceListener(DeviceID device,
                               PhysicalDeviceListener listener)
                        throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.addPhysicalDeviceListener instead.
        Adds a listener to monitor the specified physical device for events. Events report changes to the components of a physical element of the device (display, lamps and ringer). To learn how to use listeners to monitor events, see Using Listeners in the Device, Media & Call Control (DMCC) API.
        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID to which the PhysicalDeviceListener is applied.
        listener - the PhysicalDeviceListener being applied to the device. If the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        removePhysicalDeviceListener(ch.ecma.csta.binding.DeviceID, ch.ecma.csta.physical.PhysicalDeviceListener)

      • removePhysicalDeviceListener

        void removePhysicalDeviceListener(DeviceID device,
                                  PhysicalDeviceListener listener)
                           throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.removePhysicalDeviceListener instead.
        Removes a previously specified physical device listener. It is possible for a callback to be issued on a listener after it has been removed.
        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID whose PhysicalDeviceListener is to be removed.
        listener - the PhysicalDeviceListener being removed from the device. If the specified listener is not one that was previously added, then no exception is thrown and no function is performed. Also, if the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - indicates that there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        ServiceNotSupportedException - indicates that the requested service is not supported
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        addPhysicalDeviceListener(ch.ecma.csta.binding.DeviceID, ch.ecma.csta.physical.PhysicalDeviceListener)
